title: Mapping Density in Tribological Coatings After Wear Testing Using Low-Loss EELS
content: Tribological coatings are important engineering materials that reduce friction and provide resistance to wear in mechanical systems. These coatings can have self-lubricating properties that reduce the need for external lubricants and enhance the function of moving parts. Understanding of the nano- and atomic-scale structure of these coatings can elucidate the mechanisms of wear and durability, which enables the design of long-life dynamic mechanical components. The ability to measure the homogeneity of these coatings, and specifically, the density variation as a function of position and the distribution of defects provides information that can be used to understand how these coatings function and how they will degrade over time. A description of the evolution of density and atomic structure as the surfaces slide together could be used to develop mechanistic models that predict performance under loads over time.
